posts.footer: Mount Washington Observatory in New Hampshire, where, as in much of the northern United States, the aurora borealis has been unusually visible due to a solar storm, via Twitter

summaries.body: Clouds are thickening & lowering but the #aurora is still visible to our NE @ 0100 EDT #nh… http://t.co/pcEFXeqVHz http://t.co/xmxFkuEqSx
All commercial flights in New Zealand were grounded because of a radar failure, officials said.

posts.footer: The Associated Press | The New York Times

summaries.body: The son of the Samsung conglomerate's chairman apologized for the role a Samsung hospital played in South Korea's MERS outbreak.
Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration is expected to add the Lunar New Year to New York City's public school calendar, a holiday important to the city's Asian families.

posts.footer: Dilxat Raxit, a spokesman for a Uighur exile group, on a government-sponsored beer festival held shortly before Ramadan in a Muslim area of western China, via Reuters

summaries.body: This is an open provocation to the Islamic faith.
The South Korean novelist Shin Kyung-sook, author of "Please Look After Mom," apologized after being accused of plagiarizing work by the Japanese writer Yukio Mishima years ago.
Unicef reported a grim forecast for the world's poorest children over the next 15 years, saying many millions face preventable deaths, diseases, stunted growth and illiteracy.
The lion, reclusive cave crabs and the world's rarest sea lion are among the nearly 23,000 species at risk of dying out, a conservation group warned.
Advocates for third-party groups sued the F.E.C., contending the debates commission illegally excludes candidates who are not members of one of the two major parties.

display_asset.caption: Men in Pakistan cool themselves in a river near Islamabad during a heatwave. The Lancet study is part of an effort to look at how climate might change life on earth for people.

summaries.body: More people will be exposed to extreme weather associated with climate change over the next century than previously thought, a report said. Above, men in Pakistan cool down.
The Post and Courier, a newspaper in Charleston, S.C., is asking every state legislator for his or her view on removing the Confederate flag from the Capitol grounds.
Three men who parachuted off the 1 World Trade Center tower were acquitted on the most serious felony charge against them but convicted of three misdemeanors.
Walmart said it will remove all Confederate flag merchandise, including attire that features the flag's design, from its stores.
Sean Combs, known as P. Diddy, was arrested on the U.C.L.A. campus and charged with assault with a deadly weapon, which was a kettlebell.
NBC canceled "Hannibal," which stars Mads Mikkelsen, above, as the serial killer Hannibal Lecter. The show was critically praised but had low ratings.
The Supreme Court stood by a 1964 decision in a patent case, ruling against an inventor who had unwittingly signed an unfavorable contract related to a Spider-Man toy.
Two new cases of Ebola were reported in Freetown, Sierra Leone's capital, dampening hopes that the city had defeated the virus after three weeks without new cases.
A Human Rights Watch report says the World Bank does little to protect critics of its projects who are harassed and intimidated by governments that benefit from its loans.
Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina, addressing calls for the removal of the Confederate flag, said it is "time to move the flag from the Capitol grounds."
NBC Entertainment and Universal Studios said they will develop "Bombshell," the musical about Marilyn Monroe that originated as part of the TV show “Smash.”

display_asset.caption: Low water levels caused by drought at the New Melones Lake reservoir in central California.

summaries.body: Without curbing emissions, Americans by the end of the century may pay $3.1 billion in damages from rising sea levels and $180 billion in economic losses, a report says.

display_asset.caption: A privacy rights group known as EPIC said in a letter to the F.T.C. that Uber had “a history of abusing the location data of its customers.”
display_asset.credit: Allison Shelley for The New York Times

summaries.body: A privacy group is trying to block Uber from collecting customer's data and using their contact lists to send promotions.
Previously undisclosed documents indicate Pete Rose bet on baseball while playing, which he has denied for 26 years. Rose did not comment on the specifics.
A North Carolina man has been charged with plotting to buy a semiautomatic rifle and use it to kill Americans to show support for ISIS, the justice department said.
Sister Megan Rice, an antinuclear activist who spent two years in jail for vandalizing a bunker with uranium, will remain free after the government said it will not file an appeal.
Authorities in Chile declared a pollution emergency for the Santiago region Monday, forcing cars to stay off the roads and hundreds of businesses to temporarily close.
Darryl Hamilton, a former Mets player, was found dead in a Houston home in an apparent murder-suicide, the police said. The body of a woman, Monica Jordan, was also found.
Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, once valued at $1 billion, sold for $200 million to Sequential Brands Group.
Russia reacted furiously to the extension of E.U. sanctions amid the crisis in Ukraine, and said it would retaliate with an extension of countersanctions.
Twitter appointed Spencer Stuart, an executive recruiting firm, to find a replacement for its chief executive, Dick Costolo, who is stepping down on July 1.
An early election in Turkey is the "most remote" option, said Numan Kurtulmus, a deputy prime minister, after the ruling AK Party failed to win enough seats in parliament.
General Mills said it will get rid of artificial flavors and colors from its cereals by 2017, joining other brands that have dropped such ingredients in response to consumers.
Previously owned U.S. homes sold in May at the fastest pace since November 2009, a new report said, suggesting the real estate market is gaining momentum.

display_asset.credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times

summaries.body: A judge approved a deal keeping Sweet Briar College, the women’s liberal arts school in rural Virginia, open next year. The deal includes board elections and donations.
The Supreme Court has struck down a Los Angeles ordinance that permits the police to check registries at motels and hotels at any hour of the day or night.

posts.footer: Nicki Sorensen, a Tour de France cyclist, via Reuters

summaries.body: I've doped, I've admitted that fully and wholly. I'm saddened by it and I wish I could go back and undo it.
The leaders of South Korea and Japan called for their countries to leave behind historical disputes and improve ties, in a rare exchange of conciliatory remarks.
Germany released Ahmed Mansour, an Al Jazeera journalist, after detaining him on Sunday in Berlin at the request of Egypt, which charged him with crimes he denies.
The U.S. Army has reprimanded a general involved in the fight against ISIS because he guided a contract to a firm run by his former classmates at West Point, officials said.
Five cities in Texas, helped by the shale oil boom, and San Jose in Silicon Valley are among the 15 American cities that recovered the most since the recession ended in 2009.
A man who flew a gyrocopter through restricted airspace before landing at the U.S. Capitol said he rejected a plea offer that would have involved several years in prison.
President Obama used the n-word in talking about the persistence of racism in America in an interview on the podcast WTF, perhaps for the first time publicly as president.
Nearly 150 people died from heatstroke in the Pakistani city of Karachi in the past two days, as temperatures reached 113 degrees amid a power failure.
Facebook is gaining ground on Google's YouTube as an outlet for big companies to market their products via online videos, a report said.
Syrians in Turkey are returning across the border to Tal Abyad after Kurdish forces captured the town from ISIS last week. The fighting had prompted thousands to flee.
South Korea's policy makers said they were considering a spending increase to help stimulate the economy after the MERS outbreak scared off tourists and consumers.
The European Union began a naval operation to try to stop human traffickers from bringing migrants across the Mediterranean Sea to Europe in unseaworthy boats.
Search teams in New Mexico have found the body of Walter Scheib, the former White House chef who was last seen setting off for a solo hike in the mountains near Taos.
E.U. foreign ministers have extended sanctions against Russia that were initially imposed in response to the conflict in Crimea and Ukraine, a spokeswoman said.
The annual Yulin Summer Solstice Lychee and Dog Meat Festival in southwestern China has begun, despite growing uproar on the part of animal rights activists.
Employees at the British Ministry of Justice have been told by its leader, Michael Gove, never to use the word impact as a verb and to spell out contractions.
The first pilgrims have entered Tibet through a crossing that China opened to Indians who wish to visit Mount Kailash, one of the holiest sites in Hinduism and Buddhism.

display_asset.caption: The Taliban have met with female activists, including Shukria Barakzai, left, an Afghan lawmaker.

summaries.body: As they make battlefield gains, Taliban delegates in Afghanistan are engaged in peace talks and showing signs of moving away from some of their hard-line stances.

posts.footer: Hugh de Kretser, the director of the Human Rights Law Center, on reports that the Australian authorities paid a migrants smuggler to take his cargo to Indonesia, via The New York Times.

summaries.body: Australia is moving to ever more radical measures to avoid our international obligations. But the world is watching.

asset.embed_html: <iframe class="embedly-embed" src="//cdn.embedly.com/widgets/media.html?src=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fembed%2FLo7EwqOQC4o%3Ffeature%3Doembed&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DLo7EwqOQC4o%26feature%3Dyoutu.be&image=https%3A%2F%2Fi.ytimg.com%2Fvi%2FLo7EwqOQC4o%2Fhqdefault.jpg&key=170aca4a25074a88942b11f27e7ca43f&type=text%2Fhtml&schema=youtube" width="854" height="480" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

summaries.body: Thomas Fuller on the particular quirk that persists from the days of Myanmar's authoritarian rule: The country remains obsessed with pristine dollar bills.

posts.footer: The Associated Press on Serge Atlaoui, who got a reprieve from execution in April, via Twitter

summaries.body: BREAKING: Indonesian court rejects final appeal of French national facing execution for drug offenses
North Korea canceled plans to attend the University Games in South Korea because of the planned opening of a United Nations human rights office in Seoul, South Korea reported.

posts.footer: A tweet by Tullian Tchividjian, a grandson of Billy Graham, who resigned from a megachurch in Florida after admitting he had an affair, via Twitter

summaries.body: Welcome to the valley of the shadow of death...thank God grace reigns here.
Europol, the European police agency, will track and block social media accounts linked to the Islamic State, many of which are used to recruit new members.

display_asset.caption: Tombstones of relatives of Zhou Yongkang, an official who was sentenced to life over graft. A new app and online platform let citizens to report suspected corruption.

summaries.body: China's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection is allowing users of it mobile app and online platform to report corruption and violations of party discipline.
Eight people were indicted on suspicion of selling millions of bottles of counterfeit 5-Hour Energy drinks that were intended to be sold in Mexico.

display_asset.credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times

summaries.body: The U.S. government crushed more than a ton of illegally poached ivory in Times Square, a display meant to signal a crackdown on the ivory market.
Neymar, the Brazilian soccer star, was suspended for four games for his part in a fracas at the end of a recent loss to Colombia and will miss the rest of the Copa America.
A state board revoked the license of a former U.S. Army doctor, finding that his "bizarre" training methods for troops was "abhorrent and abnormal."
Jason Day collapsed, apparently from a dizzy spell, on the final hole of his round at the U.S. Open. He finished the hole (with a bogey) after lying on the grass for several minutes.
Tiger Woods shot a six-over 76 in the second round of the U.S. Open, most likely ensuring that he will miss the cut for just the fifth time as a professional.
Prosecutors rested their case in the trial of James E. Holmes, who is charged with killing 12 people in a Colorado theater in 2012, after an emotional final witness.
The Texas Supreme Court upheld a divorce granted in a lower court for a same-sex couple, a precedent-setting decision in a state with a same-sex marriage ban.
The Philae spacecraft that landed on a speeding comet last fall made contact again after a five-day gap, the European Space Agency said. It awoke this week after seven months.
Oakland hosted a parade for the N.B.A. champion Golden State Warriors. Above, Stephen Curry acknowledges the crowd.
Rand Paul appointed Mark Spitznagel, the hedge fund manager, as a senior economic adviser as Mr. Paul seeks the Republican presidential nomination.
Children as young as 3 have a sense of justice and are sensitive to the harm of others, preferring to help victims than punish perpetrators, scientists found.
Google said it will create a process that will allow victims of "revenge porn" to request removal of those images from the search engine.

display_asset.caption: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida spoke at the Faith and Freedom Coalition's Road to Majority Conference in Washington on Friday.

summaries.body: Jeb Bush told a gathering of religious conservatives that the fight over same-sex marriage should continue regardless of what the Supreme Court decides in a coming case.
Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece joined President Vladimir V. Putin at an economic forum in Russia, a visit seen as an effort to pressure Europe’s leaders in debt talks.
A hospital in Thailand known for treating medical tourists said it quarantined 58 staff members after authorities confirmed its first case of MERS.
Retirement communities in Florida are expected to show the most economic growth in America in 2016, replacing oil towns, a new report on urban areas said.

posts.footer: The Associated Press | The New York Times

summaries.body: The Obama administration unveiled rules intended to improve fuel efficiency for medium-size and heavy-duty trucks and to cut pollution blamed for global warming.
Toyota in Japan is defending its diversity initiative after Julie Hamp, the first foreign executive to work for the company there, was arrested for illegally bringing a painkiller into Japan.
Extremists in Afghanistan, Iraq and Nigeria were mostly responsible for a nearly 35 percent rise in the number of terrorist attacks in 2014, a State Department report said.

display_asset.caption: A fisherman holding an endangered vaquita porpoise that was caught in a gill net for sharks and other fish in the Gulf of Mexico.

summaries.body: The world’s most endangered porpoise is disappearing faster than previously believed, threatened by gill-fishing nets in the Gulf of California, a new report said.
Mo Farah, the distance runner and two-time Olympic champion, said he had never taken performance-enhancing drugs and described two missed tests as "simple mistakes."
Jon Stewart of "The Daily Show" avoided jokes in his monologue Thursday. Instead, he spoke of the Charleston shooting, including the reluctance of some to call it a terrorist attack.
Britain is investigating whether a man found dead on a roof was a stowaway who fell from a plane. A second person suspected of being a stowaway was found alive on a flight.
Ten Tunisian diplomats seized by Libyan gunmen last week have been released, Tunisia's foreign minister said, while denying they had been traded for a Libyan militia leader.
The U.N. said $1.6 billion in aid is needed for Yemen, where about 21 million people are struggling to find food and shelter after Saudi-led airstrikes against Houthi fighters.
North Korea said it had succeeded where the top minds in science have failed, state news media reported, developing a drug that can cure MERS, Ebola, SARS and AIDS.
A cruise ship crashed into a wall in the Eisenhower Lock in upstate New York on Thursday night, the Coast Guard said, injuring more than a dozen passengers.

posts.footer: A Times correspondent, on efforts to reach a deal on an international bailout for Greece, via Twitter

summaries.body: ECB Council to hold midday teleconference on request for more emergency assistance to Greek banks after #eurogroup deadlocks, again. @ecb
Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, which has hanged more than 170 people since December, ordered a halt to executions for Ramadan.

posts.footer: Le Monde, the influential French newspaper, in an English-language editorial

summaries.body: Today, we solemnly say to our friends across the Channel: beware, Brexit could be your Waterloo!
Danish voters ousted their center-left government in a clear swing to the right that unexpectedly elevated an anti-immigrant, anti-European Union party.
Vietnam, whose tourism industry is flagging, said visitors from five European countries could enter without a visa.
Julie Gayet has appeared for the first time at an official ceremony with President François Hollande, amid reports that she is gradually becoming France’s first lady.
At least 25 people died after drinking toxic liquor in suburban Mumbai, India, the police said.

posts.footer: A Times correspondent in Southeast Asia on Burmese money changers' curious reluctance to accept U.S. bills with the merest crease or tear, via Twitter

summaries.body: Myanmar's Obsession With Clean Cash: the bane of visitors. NYT video from Yangon: https://t.co/osa4yq4nqF
Thailand cautioned transgender migrant workers against public cross-dressing in the Middle East, after two Thais in the United Arab Emirates were said to have been detained.
The Federal Communications Commission voted to explore subsidizing broadband Internet access for poor Americans.

posts.footer: Zhanna Nemtsova, whose father, the opposition figure Boris Y. Nemtsov, was killed in Moscow in February, and who blames the Russian media in part for his death, via The Guardian

summaries.body: Many of the articles printed by the Kremlin-controlled media ape the divisive rhetoric of Rwanda before the genocide.

posts.footer: The South China Morning Post | The New York Times

summaries.body: A prominent Hong Kong lawmaker wept during a radio appearance over her failure to vote for Beijing's election plan for the city due to a parliamentary blunder.
